LanguageData.PRF_Recycler_HelpText: This machine can recycle almost any apparel or weapon down to its raw resources with decent efficiency. Requires the output to be cleared so that new material can be ejected.
LanguageData.PRF_RecipeDatabase_HelpText:
To start importing recipes, place this near a powered worktable, go to "Import recipe...", and select the recipe you want to import.

Afterwards reinstall this near assembler(s) to share recipes.

Can store multiple recipes from different workbenches.
LanguageData.PRF_TypeOneAssembler_I_HelpText:
To get any assembler building set up, go to its "Bills" tab and add the bills you want in order. Then configure its output so that the yellow cell is where you want the products to go. Finally, place the required ingredients around it (if you're using a smart hopper, remember to check "toggle allow forbidden"), and give it power.

To feed recipes into this assembler, build a recipe database and place it next to the work table you want to copy bills from(See the recipe database help for additional instructions). Once finished with the import(s), reinstall it near this building.

Please note max level recipes for this assembler is: 10, art level is 9
LanguageData.PRF_TypeTwoAssembler_I_HelpText:
This assembler is special in that it gets faster and better quality at its recipes the more it works on them. Over time, however, this skill also decays exponentially.

To get any assembler building set up, go to its "Bills" tab and add the bills you want in order. Then configure its output so that the yellow cell is where you want the products to go. Finally, place the required ingredients around it (if you're using a smart hopper, remember to check "toggle allow forbidden"), and give it power.

To feed recipes into this assembler, build a recipe database and place it next to the work table you want to copy bills from. See the help for the recipe database for additional instructions. Once finished with the import(s), reinstall it near this building.

Please note max level recipes for this assembler is: 20, art level is 12
LanguageData.Lighting_FloorLampArrow_HelpText: Signs to indicate what direction things go in or just to decorate your factory. Based off the same bioluminescent good used by insectoids.
LanguageData.Lighting_RedFloorLampArrow_HelpText: Signs to indicate what direction things go in or just to decorate your factory. Based off the same bioluminescent good used by insectoids.
LanguageData.Lighting_GreenFloorLampArrow_HelpText: Signs to indicate what direction things go in or just to decorate your factory. Based off the same bioluminescent good used by insectoids.
LanguageData.Lighting_FloorLampX_HelpText: Signs to indicate what direction things go in or just to decorate your factory. Based off the same bioluminescent good used by insectoids.
LanguageData.PRF_Shearer_HelpText: Automatically shears animals when they venture near the vicinity of the building. Store food as bait for the animals so that they wander nearby to be sheared.
LanguageData.PRF_Milker_HelpText: Automatically milks animals when they venture near the vicinity of the building. Store food as bait for the animals so that they wander nearby to be milked.
LanguageData.PRF_GenericAnimalHarvester_HelpText: Automatically harvests animals when they venture near the vicinity of the building. Store food as bait for the animals so that they wander nearby to be harvested.
LanguageData.PRF_GenericAnimalHarvester_II_HelpText: Automatically harvests animals when they venture near the vicinity of the building. Store food as bait for the animals so that they wander nearby to be harvested
LanguageData.PRF_Slaughterhouse_HelpText: Automatically slaughters animals if they meet specified criteria: age, gender, quantity, pregnancy status, bonded, trained. Also check out the Auto Meat Grinder and Animal Harvesting stations.
LanguageData.PRF_BillTypeMiner_I_HelpText: The Tier 3 Plasma Drill produces specific resources from underground which can be specified by bills. It will not draw the attention of insectoids.
LanguageData.PRF_DeepQuarry_mkIII_HelpText: The Tier 3 Random Pulse Drill produces random valuable resources from underground. It will not draw the attention of insectoids, and unlike previous versions never produces rock chunks, meaning the output is always some kind of valuable metal or component.
LanguageData.PRF_DeepQuarry_mkII_helpText: The Tier 2 Pulse Drill produces a random resource from underground once every three hours. This will work with any resource available in your world, though it's based on the same commonality as world generation itself, so most of the devices output will be random rock chunks. This device can draw the attention of underground insectoids.
LanguageData.PRF_DeepQuarry_mkI_HelpText: The Tier 1 Auger Drill produces a random resource from underground once every eight hours. This will work with any resource available in your world, though it's based on the same commonality as world generation itself, so most of the devices output will be random rock chunks. This device can draw the attention of underground insectoids.
LanguageData.PRF_SelfPrepper_HelpText: An automatic food preparation table. Input raw food, output ingredients to make food.
LanguageData.PRF_MeatGrinder_HelpText: This dangerous-looking machine accepts dead creatures as input and outputs meat, hide, and any other byproduct. Be sure to empty the output quickly, as it can only output one type of item at a time.
LanguageData.PRF_SelfCookerI_HelpText:
To get this building set up go to its "Bills" tab and add the bills you want in order. Then, configure its output so that the yellow cell is where you want the products to go. Finally, place the required ingredients around it (if you're using a smart hopper, remember to check "toggle allow forbidden"), and give it power.

Please note max level recipes for this assembler is: 8

It will ONLY cook simple foods. Upgrade to get more complicated food types.
LanguageData.PRF_SelfCookerII_HelpText:
To get this building set up go to its "Bills" tab and add the bills you want in order. Then, configure its output so that the yellow cell is where you want the products to go. Finally, place the required ingredients around it (if you're using a smart hopper, remember to check "toggle allow forbidden"), and give it power.

Please note max level recipes for this assembler is: 12

This one copies recipes from the Electric stove, but ONLY upto level 12 cooking.
LanguageData.PRF_SelfCookerIII_HelpText:
To get this building set up go to its "Bills" tab and add the bills you want in order. Then, configure its output so that the yellow cell is where you want the products to go. Finally, place the required ingredients around it (if you're using a smart hopper, remember to check "toggle allow forbidden"), and give it power.

Please note max level recipes for this assembler is: 20

This one copies recipes from the Electric stove, and will never spoil or poison a meal.
LanguageData.PRF_FermentingBarrel_HelpText: To get this building set up go to the âBillsâ tab and add the bills you want in order. Then, configure the output so that the yellow cell is where you want the beer to be placed after fermentation. Finally, place wort around it (if you are using a smart hopper, remember to check toggle âallow forbiddenâ), and give it power.
LanguageData.PRF_WoodCrate_I_HelpText: To output to crates and cargo platforms with the "Industrial Rollers" mod, remember to use a roller pusher at the end.
LanguageData.PRF_WoodCrate_II_HelpText: To output to crates and cargo platforms with the "Industrial Rollers" mod, remember to use a roller pusher at the end.
LanguageData.PRF_SteelCrate_I_HelpText: To output to crates and cargo platforms with the "Industrial Rollers" mod, remember to use a roller pusher at the end.
LanguageData.PRF_SteelCrate_II_HelpText: To output to crates and cargo platforms with the "Industrial Rollers" mod, remember to use a roller pusher at the end.
LanguageData.PRF_DigitalStorageUnit_I_HelpText:
The Digital Storage Unit (DSU) functions like any other storage building, except all items put inside are moved to the middle cell, allowing for virtually infinite storage capacity. Thereâs a limit defined in mod settings, and if set too high it might cause lag.

To prevent considerable lag in heavily used cargo platforms, the item readout in the "Items" tab only displays the first 500 items. You can, however, search for the item you want using the search bar.

NOTE: To output to crates and cargo platforms with the "Industrial Rollers" mod, remember to use a roller pusher at the end.
To set direct DSU output right-click the desired output item in the DSU item list to have it move to the DSU output cell. 
You can also right click and select a pawn and force wear to equip items from storage

 The Pawn Access button controls whether pawns can directly interact with the DSU or if they have to use the I/O port.
LanguageData.PRF_IOPort_I_HelpText: To configure the storage unit I/O port, set the mode (input or output), and the unit you want to connect to. If you choose output, remember to also select the item that you want to pull.\nYou can use right click on storage tab to directly output that item or stack into the selected I/O port.
LanguageData.PRF_IOPort_IFridge_HelpText: This works like the I/O port. \n May interact strangely with RimFridge. If it's not working, double check your settings and toggle input/output mode.
LanguageData.PRF_Conveyor_Simple_I_HelpText:
Conveyor belts will send items along their path. They automatically connect to other belts, including other belts facing different directions, excluding belts facing each other. You can split stacks or selectively filter items to other belts using belt splitters (so long as the belt and splitter are both above or below ground). Linking above and below ground belts requires a subterranean entrance or exit, but pullers do not require this conversion regardless of their position.

 Belts are not sophisticated, they will shove the objects into any empty space in front of it, including storage containers and stockpiles. They also do not obey filter settings, this function requires using pullers.

You can set any segment as the "end belt" in settings to make the item stop in order to be used by an assembler, this does not require a shelf or hopper.
LanguageData.PRF_Conveyor_Wall_I_HelpText: Wall conveyor belts function similarly to standard conveyor belts except that they keep rooms insulated from one another. They work in conjunction with all puller types and link seamlessly with standard belts. You can direct their output into storage without using a puller.
LanguageData.PRF_Conveyor_UG_I_HelpText: Underground belts are capable of going under machinery and walls without issue. However, they do not interact with standard belts unless linked with subterranean entrances and exits. Underground belts also require the use of a puller or subterranean exit in order to retrieve items from underground. Keep in mind that splitters must also match: Above ground belts use above ground splitters, and underground belts use underground splitters.
LanguageData.PRF_Conveyor_Connector_To_UG_HelpText: Underground entrance: Required for use to merge standard belts with underground belts, however they are not required in order to iniate any length of underground belt. In other words, you can link an above ground puller directly to standard underground belt to send it underground.
LanguageData.PRF_Conveyor_Connector_To_Floor_HelpText: Underground exit: Required by underground belts in order to exit or interact with above ground storage, stockpiles, and belts. Without an exit, an unterminated underground belt will carry items until something pulls it or another section of underground belt is added.
LanguageData.PRF_Conveyor_Splitter_I_HelpText: Conveyer belt splitters work by splitting or filtering objects on a belt into two or three other directions. To do this, face the splitter away from your current belt then enable the output directions in settings. Each direction must be selected then enabled, and each direction has their own sets of filters. For instance: You can select North, enable North, and only select "chunks", then select and enable East, selecting everything but chunks. This would effectively filter any amount of chunks to the North, and the belt would continue East. With everything selected, the splitter splits stacks. With nothing selected, the splitter holds items.
LanguageData.PRF_FuelingMachine_HelpText:
The fueling machine is quite easy to use. Point the robotic arm designated by the yellow cell at the structure you want to fuel, place fuel next to it in the white cells and give it power.
Refuels most standard refuelables.
It is also capable of fueling mortars and some modded mortars/turrets.
(Supports CE turrets and SoS Torpedos)
LanguageData.PRF_SimplePuller_I_HelpText:
A simple item puller, slower than later versions.

It can pull from belts, crates, DSU, stockpile zones, shelves, and smart hoppers. Is toggled off by default and requires being activated in order to function. Not required to terminate a belt into storage, but can help with more advanced logic. To get better control, set filters and settings. By default, pullers will not output if item is not allowed in target destination or if output is blocked by a wall or another item.

Yellow cell = output
White cell = input.
LanguageData.PRF_GrowzonePuller_I_HelpText: Works similarly to other pullers, but this one only is able to pull from growzones.
LanguageData.PRF_SimplePuller_II_HelpText: Latest-generation MKII pullers that have some more options than the Industrial Roller version. This can properly connect in some cases where Industrial Rollers cannot.
LanguageData.PRF_SimplePuller_II_Wall_HelpText: This is walled version of the MKII puller. It has more options than the Industrial Roller version. This can properly connect in some cases where Industrial Rollers cannot.
LanguageData.PRF_SimplePuller_II_Side_HelpText: An angled puller that works at 90 degree angles. Has similar features to the standard puller, with yellow cells as output and white cells as input. The direction can be changed after placing.Might be usefull in some cases
LanguageData.PRF_SmartHopper_HelpText: The Smart Hopper pulls in nearby items from the ground or stockpile cells onto itself and holds until an assembler can use it.\n\n If you want to use it on an assembler, remember to enable the assembler's "toggle allow forbidden" option to allow assembler to pull from the hopper.
LanguageData.PRF_DroneCultivator_I_HelpText: The first automated cultivator, this device utilises simple drones to sow, water, and harvest your crops. It is slow but still represents a good first step into automated farming.
LanguageData.PRF_DroneCultivator_II_HelpText: The Mark II Automated cultivator. By using improved drones to do your agriculture jobs, the functionality of automated farming operations is greatly improved. The drones will haul to a stockpile, I/O, or crate if it's within range.
LanguageData.PRF_DroneCultivator_II_sun_HelpText: The Mark II Automated cultivator. By using improved drones to do your agriculture jobs, the functionality of automated farming operations is greatly improved. The drones will haul to a stockpile, I/O, or crate if it's within range. This version includes an integrated sunlamp and can be upgraded.
LanguageData.PRF_DroneCultivator_III_HelpText: The Mark III Automated cultivator. With the use of extremely advanced automated drones this device can take your farming operations to the next level. The included drones will haul to a stockpile, I/O, crate if its within range.
LanguageData.PRF_OldTypeCultivator_I_HelpText: An alternative form of high-tech Cultivator that houses worker mechanites instead of drones. The mechanites can sow, harvest and maintain a growzone or hydroponics setup. It will also output onto a cell for further processing.
LanguageData.PRF_OldTypeCultivator_Sun_HelpText: An alternative form of high-tech Cultivator that houses worker mechanites instead of drones. The mechanites can sow, harvest and maintain a growzone or hydroponics setup. It will also output onto a cell for further processing. This model has an integrated sunlamp.
LanguageData.PRF_OldTypeCultivator_Xl_HelpText: A highly advanced XL Cultivator that houses worker mechanites instead of drones. The included mechanites will sow, harvest and maintain a growzone or hydroponics setup. It will also output onto a cell for further processing.
LanguageData.PRF_Sprinkler_I_HelpText: A building that waters plants in an expanding radius, increasing their growth by one hour per round. Effects are stackable.
LanguageData.PRF_Sprinkler_II_HelpText: An upgraded sprinkler using advanced AI to calculate and distribute the fertilizer needs of each plant in each sprinkle, optimizing the growth rate of every plant. Affected plants have their growth increased by two hours per round. Effects are stackable.
LanguageData.PRF_AutoCrafterSimple_HelpText:
The S.A.L is an old type of Assembler which can be set up as a "stationary pawn" on any workbench Worker slot.
It will then start working on any bill setup in your workbench if it has required skill level and resource within its pulling range (white cells around it)

Each S.A.L has a preset set of skill and can perform certain task better than others, so pick the right one for the job.

S.A.L stands for Station Automation and Logistics, and was the original autocrafting mechanism in RimFactory before the creation of the standalone crafting machines..
LanguageData.PRF_AutoCrafter_HelpText:
The S.A.L is an old type of Assembler which can be set up as a "stationary pawn" on any workbench Worker slot.
It will then start working on any bill setup in your workbench if it has required skill level and resource within its pulling range (white cells around it)

Each S.A.L has a preset set of skill and can perform certain task better than others, so pick the right one for the job.

S.A.L stands for Station Automation and Logistics, and was the original autocrafting mechanism in RimFactory before the creation of the standalone crafting machines.

The S.A.L is an old type of Assembler which can be set up as a "stationary pawn" on any workbench Worker slot.
It will then start working on any bill setup in your workbench if it has required skill level and resource within its pulling range (white cells around it)

Each S.A.L has a preset set of skill and can perform certain task better than others, so pick the right one for the job.

S.A.L stands for Station Automation and Logistics, and was the original autocrafting mechanism in RimFactory before the creation of the standalone crafting machines.

The S.A.L is an old type of Assembler which can be set up as a "stationary pawn" on any workbench Worker slot.
It will then start working on any bill setup in your workbench if it has required skill level and resource within its pulling range (white cells around it)

Each S.A.L has a preset set of skill and can perform certain task better than others, so pick the right one for the job.

S.A.L stands for Station Automation and Logistics, and was the original autocrafting mechanism in RimFactory before the creation of the standalone crafting machines.
LanguageData.PRF_OverclockedAutoAssembler_HelpText:
The S.A.L is an old type of Assembler which can be set up as a "stationary pawn" on any workbench Worker slot.
It will then start working on any bill setup in your workbench if it has required skill level and resource within its pulling range (white cells around it)

Each S.A.L has a preset set of skill and can perform certain task better than others, so pick the right one for the job.

S.A.L stands for Station Automation and Logistics, and was the original autocrafting mechanism in RimFactory before the creation of the standalone crafting machines.
